ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to close read and analyze different stories and writings
Learned more about how to understand neurodiversity as a movement, concept, and identifier.
I learnt a lot about neurodivergence, which includes new perspectives on how to think of it and how they can present, especially in literature.
I think the teacher was amazing and we learned a lot of useful content!

I learned about different ways of talking about and understanding neurodiversity. I learned about common misconceptions of neurodiversity as well as various implicit biases that we unknowingly perpetuate. I also learned so much about different modalities of seeing the world through Neuro diverse minds.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed learning about the different emotions and writings from there. I did not really like spending so much time on people with mental illnesses as I cannot relate to them.

Strengths: the course was very well-organized, with the professor and TA offering continuous prompt feedback. The professor was very accommodating for assignments, and the feedback provided helped immensely for the development of my writing. The grading was very generous in this class for a writing course. The assignments built on top of each other and had a lot of flexibility built into their prompts. 

Weaknesses: I wished the other students in my class participated more. The readings were so interesting and the professor was trying her best to be engaging, but the students just did not reciprocate her enthusiasm. Granted, it is a Monday 9AM class, but still, there were so many times in which I wished that the other students would just contribute more to the conversations we were having in class.

If you don't mind the early hour, it's a great course with no real weaknesses. You learn a lot and the micro-essays can later be used for the finals, which was a huge help during finals. You get to pick from a wide variety of work to write about, many of which are works I would not otherwise seek out myself and that I found very informative and interesting to read.
I think the course was very engaging and insightful. I think the class was a little messy itself

Strengths are that she is an incredible lecturer and really makes an intellectually rich space. For this reason, I really really enjoyed going to class every Monday. The readings were also incredibly insightful and profound, and she recommended some beautiful and underrated works that really should be discussed more in academic settings.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Heck yes. Absolutely loved this class
Yes. This course could be improved to be more engaging, but it is still a very important and thought-provoking class.
I would def recommend this course for anyone who needs a writing credit. Even though its a LITR course, it's open to students of all backgrounds and interests
Yes, 100 percent. Jane was very nice and I loved it

I definitely would. I really enjoyed every aspect of it and it was clearly designed with the student intellectual experience in mind- it was designed to be curated to each students interests and passions.
